In a modus ponens argument, if the first part of the conditional statement (the antecedent, or "If Joe went to the park") is true, and the second part (the consequent, or "then Lucy went to the zoo") is also true, then the entire statement is true. 

In this case, we are given that the first part of the conditional statement is true (Joe did go to the park), and we are also given that the second part of the conditional statement is true (Joe's action of going to the park implies that Lucy went to the zoo).
